H0.text: A flood is the natural disaster least likely to cause major damage to a prairie ecosystem.

H1.text: A tornado is the natural disaster least likely to cause major damage to a prairie ecosystem.

H2.text: A hurricane is the natural disaster least likely to cause major damage to a prairie ecosystem.

H3.text: An earthquake is the natural disaster that is least likely to cause major damage to a prairie ecosystem.

A4.text: The southeastern portion of the Great Plains is the most tornado active area in the world and is sometimes referred to as Tornado Alley.

A5.text: Floods (in particular more frequent or smaller floods) can also bring many benefits, such as recharging ground water, making soil more fertile and increasing nutrients in some soils.

A6.text: Flooding can spread nutrients to lakes and rivers, which can lead to increased biomass and improved fisheries for a few years.
